Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: LAWN: Scaling Up Cellular Data Networks using a Large Number of Antennas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The exponential growth of mobile data is a major challenge to the operators of cellular networks. Looking beyond conventional capacity-improving approaches such as adding more cells and acquiring more spectrum, this project seeks to fundamentally improve the spectral efficiency of cellular data networks. The project investigates LAWN (Large number of Antenna based Wireless Networking), a radically new cellular network architecture, in which a large number of antennas simultaneously serve a relatively much smaller number of wireless terminals using multiuser beamforming. The project has two inter-related thrusts. The first investigates a novel LAWN base station design and prototype that can cost-effectively scale to hundreds of antennas and exploit physical-layer tradeoffs between computational complexity and network capacity. The second thrust studies the resulting new network architecture that efficiently schedules terminals, intelligently allocates transmission power, and coordinates pilot signal transmissions to mitigate inter-cell interference.

The project targets improving the spectral and power efficiency of cellular networks by many fold, leading to not only fast wireless data networks but also longer battery lifetime of mobile terminals. Results from the project are likely to provide fresh insights for new theoretical development, bringing large-scale multi-user beamforming one significant leap closer to practical deployment in cellular data networks. In addition to academic publications, the project will produce an open platform, including hardware, software, and documentation available on-line, for teaching and researching base station design. It will actively involve undergraduate students as well as students from under-represented populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cellular networks have become an essential component of our information based society. As a result, the traffic volumes on cellular networks have been growing exponentially, leading to serious concerns that there can be significant congestions on cellular networks, if the growth of the capacities of cellular networks cannot keep up with the growth of traffic volumes.  There are essentially three basic approaches to increase cellular capacities: more spectrum, smaller cells, or better spectrum efficiency. Traditional approaches focus on the first approach and sometimes the second, to alleviate congestion or poor coverage of certain cells. A key finding of this project is that we can significantly increase cellular network capacity through a drastic approach for improving the spectrum efficiency of cellular data networks. Going beyond existing and emerging cellular network standards, which focus on single-user communications with only one client communicating with a base station in a given time slot, spectrum channel, or code sequence, this project focuses on multiuser multiple input multiple output (MIMO), in which a base station (BS) with multiple antennas can simultaneously serve multiple single-antenna clients. Although multiuser MIMO can improve cell capacities by manifold, it faces two well-known barriers for adoption: (1) the computational complexity, which may grow beyond tractable when serving a large number of clients; (2) the effectiveness of multiuser MIMO is highly sensitive to dynamic channel state information (CSI).

The intellectual merit and the key finding of this project is that we can design and implement of LAWN, a radically new cellular network architecture, operating with a large ratio of base station antennas to clients, to achieve a large increase in spectral and power efficiency, with low computational complexity, by applying a new insight that as the ratio of antennas to clients scales up, the simplest signal processing, conjugate beamforming on the downlink and matched­filtering on the uplink, asymptotically achieves near­optimal performance, achieving scalability while lowering complexity, an unexpectedly beneficial scaling property.

The key outcomes of this project include the following three results: (1) the design and prototyping of a novel LAWN base station, which is modular, hierarchical, and can cost effectively scale to hundreds of antennas per base station; (2) the design and implementation of novel algorithms based on reciprocity to effectively estimate channel states involving a large number of antennas; (3) the design and implementation of a new network control programming framework to simplify control challenges including low-level abstractions and highly dynamic state dependency

This project achieves broader impacts by bringing multi­user beamforming one significant step closer to practical deployment in cellular data networks. The research spans both wireless communications and wireless networking, bridging the communication theory to wireless networking, further interconnecting the two communities to work together. The open base station platform and the open source controller can lead to wide dissemination, helping teaching and open research.
